content.description:
Wounded Bird has so-so climbing on somewhat ledgy terrain to a nice belay ledge shared with

The Fledgling

.
content.location:
It is mid-wall just right of the tall tree and left of

The Fledgling

dihedral.

content.description:
Wings of Eagles has fun climbing in a spectacular position.

From the anchor, climb right around the arete then up and over to the obvious, hand traverse flake. Follow the flake to its end, then head up to the anchors.

To descend, itâ€˜s probably easiest to lower directly down to the

Talon Scout

anchors and from there to the ground
content.location:
Start from the ledge atop

Wounded Bird

and

The Fledgling

.

content.description:
Talon Scout climbs a weakness between the light and dark colored rock. This may be the best sport 5.11 pitch at Grazing allotment.

P1. (5.11c, fully bolted) There is a 5.10d-11a move before the first bolt, so be careful. Follow the corner system with a stemming crux at mid-height.

P2. (5.10c, gear to #4, 3 bolts) Continue up the crack system with a crux near the top.
content.location: This is the rightmost of the trio of routes behind the large tree near the wall on the NW face.

content.description:
Sunshine and Solitude climbs cracks on the face of the buttress then moves around the left arete to the steep left face. It is steep with thought provoking moves.

P1) 5.11a. Anchor your belayer at the base of the buttress, then climb a small pillar to cracks on the face. Follow the cracks to a bolt on the arete then up past three more bolts to the bolted anchor.
content.protection: Four bolts and a few 0.5 to 2 inch cams for the start.
content.location: S&S climbs the buttress on the far right side of the southeast face.  This is a new route not in the NCCC guide.  It is right of all the routes in the guide.

content.description:
This has interesting stemming up a V dihedral. It keeps your attention.

Stem the dihedral with a possible full body rotation to the anchors.
content.location:
This ascends the V dihedral left of

Joyride

.

content.description:
Perfect Donkey is another fun addition to the warm, southeast face of Grazing Allotment Crag. This route climbs a series of right-facing dihedrals.

"We went out to find a unicorn but ended up with the perfect donkey."
content.protection: Lots-o-bolts and a chain anchor. A 70m rope is required.
content.location:
It is located right of

Joy Ride

. Start on the same platform.

content.description:
This route is a variation on the 5.8 trad line Bud Collins that splits right into a thin, left-facing corner after about 30'. The NCCC guide calls it 5.11c/d, but I had a hard time finding any moves that tough, not to say it was easy...clearly it hasn't been climbed in a while and was dirty, crumbly, and had some committing face climbing with gear well below your feet. It felt like the crux was well-protected however.

The NCCC guide, along with the eye test, didn't show any anchors for lowering, I think this route is supposed to be a walkoff. I ended up doing a wonky traverse to the anchors above

High Steppin'

. A 70m rope was necessary to toprope/lower from these anchors.
content.location: It is on the left side of the south face, on the main slabby part of the wall before all the corners start further left.

content.description:
Climb the right-facing dihedral to its end, then step left, and continue up chickenheads to the anchor.

A 70m rope is required!
content.location: This ascends the obvious dihedral left of Bud Collins (The 5.8 crack on the left side of the High Steppin slab).

content.description: This 35m route on the NW face is a good warmup. A 70m rope is required to lower from the upper anchors, but there is a mid-pitch anchor on the ledge.  The crux is right before the ledge, and there is a crux leaving the ledge witch you would hit if you came off.
content.location: This is the third route from the left on the NW face.

content.description:
P1: climb up a broken corner and crack system for 4 bolts to a stance underneath a roof. Get psyched, and crank a couple bolts of cruxy climbing involving powerful moves, a bit of balancey sidepulling, and a mantel. Finish with 20 feet or so of more moderate climbing to a ledge with a chain anchor (100ish feet, 9 or 10 bolts, 13a, give or take a few letter grades).

P2: I did not climb this pitch, but apparently it is another 25m of 12a/b climbing involving techy crimps and a dihedral to finish. There is a bolted chain anchor up top.

The two pitches can be linked for a full value romp to the top of the formation, which apparently takes 15 bolts in total.
content.protection:
There are 9 or 10 bolts for the first pitch and a chain anchor. Supposedly there are 15 bolts to link both pitches.

Use a 70m rope to lower from P1. If linking, a 70m should let you lower to the P1 anchor from the top of P2, but knot your ends.
content.location: This route ascends the face of the very obvious pillar on the right side of the southwest face. I think it's the first bolted route you get to on the main face of the crag if you take the left fork.

content.description: Head up past a cruxy move between the second and third bolts then up easier terrain to a traverse to the upper buttress. Continue up the upper buttress passing a second crux at the roof to the anchors.
content.location: This is just right of the far left lowest toe of Grazing Allotment Crag as seen from the parking area. The trail to the backside passes right under it. See the photo.

content.description:
High Steppin' has lots of high steppin' onto slabby footholds. This is a new route not in the NCCC 1st edition guide.

P1) 5.10a: climb the slab just left of Solar Slab past a bolt. Continue up past ten more bolts to the bolted anchors. ***A SEVENTY METER ROPE IS MANDATORY FOR LOWERING.*** You can rap to the ledge between the first and second bolts with a 60 meter rope and downclimb left.

Toprope variation, 5.10a: at the seventh bolt, angle up and right to a flake, ascend it to its top, then work back left and up to the anchors.
content.protection: Eleven bolts to a bolted anchor. You can use an optional 0.5 or 0.75 inch cam between the first and second bolts.
content.location: On the SE face, it climbs the slab between Solar Slab and Bud Collins. See the NCCC guide for location of SS and BC.

content.description: Clip the first two bolts, and angle left. There is a crux at bolt 4 and one higher up. Some of the holds are not as positive as you would like.
content.location:
This is just left of

Talon Scout

on the NW face. It is the middle of the trio of routes behind the large tree at the base.

content.description:
This line would be a classic at any crag, and it doesn't suffer from lichen like some of the other NW face routes.

Head up easy rock, and clip the only bolt on the route. Step left, and continue up the leaning dihedral. The climbing is mostly 5.10 until the final bulge. Get creative with liebacks, palming, and stems which lead to an anchor.
content.protection: One set of offset nuts, one set of cams to #2 Camalot, and extra finger-sized cams.
content.location: This ascends the leaning dihedral as you turn the corner to the NW face.

content.description:
Cowabunga has nice climbing.

Climb an easy slab to the base of an orange streak. Continue up the bolt line passing a couple cruxes to the anchors.
content.location:
This is the rightmost route on this section of cliff just right of

Bodacious

.

content.description: Casanova is a fun, thin crack protected down low by a single bolt.
content.location: It is on the SW face, just to the left of the overhanging corners with the hard climbs.

content.description: Head up to the shared bolt at 25 feet (optional 0.75 cam), Run it out to the bolts on the headwall. The crux comes at the second bulge. Figure out how to grab the nipple, and high step to better holds. This route is rated 11a in the guidebook, but I think you may find it more difficult.
content.location: This is the second route from the right on the SE face.

content.description: Climb one of the routes on the left side of the wall, and move over to the anchor to the right of the base of the huge, left-facing dihedral that is the second pitch of Kestrel Corner. Fun stemming and techy climbing leads up the left-facing dihedral to a set of anchors.
content.location: This is a second pitch to Battle Wound. It goes up the left-facing dihedral just right of the huge, left-facing dihedral that is the second pitch of Kestral Corner.
